title: UNICEF Angola Flash Update No. 1 (Cholera), 07-14 January 2025 - ReliefWeb
summary:
UNICEF Angola Flash Update No. 1 (Cholera), 07-14 January 2025

Posted: 15 Jan 2025 | Source: UNICEF

This report provides an overview of the cholera outbreak in Angola, which declared its first case on January 7, 2025. The outbreak has significantly affected children and women.

  • 3 out of 21 provinces affected: Bengo, Luanda, and Icolo e Bengo.
  • 11 out of 326 municipalities affected.
  • Total of 332 cases reported, including 66 confirmed and 20 deaths; Luanda province has the highest number of cases (259).
  • Children and women are significantly affected, with the highest case count in ages 0-9 (32.2%).
  • 10 deaths reported in the 0-9 age group.
"The Technical Commission activated the National Plan for Cholera Response and mobilized resources for health workers and medical staff."

This situation calls for urgent response measures to manage the outbreak and prevent further spread.
newTitle: UNICEF Angola Flash Update No. 1 (Cholera) - January 2025

The article explores how consuming alcohol at specific times can hinder weight loss goals, leveraging expert opinions.

  • Alcohol can interfere with metabolic processes.
  • Timing of alcohol consumption matters more than quantity.
  • Experts recommend avoiding alcohol around workout times for better results.
“Timing your alcohol intake can significantly influence your weight loss success,” says the expert.

In conclusion, mindful consumption of alcohol is crucial for those seeking to lose weight effectively.

title: Chameleon-like immune cells may worsen asthma - Medical Xpress
summary:
Chameleon-like Immune Cells May Worsen Asthma

Date: January 15, 2025 | Source: Medical Xpress

Researchers at McMaster University have identified a new population of immune cells that may significantly contribute to asthma severity.

  • The study, published in Science Translational Medicine, explores the complex mechanisms of severe asthma.
  • Asthma affects up to 10% of the general asthma population and is challenging to treat.
  • Chameleon-like immune cells (c-kit+IL-17A+ ILC2s) linked to eosinophils and neutrophils might worsen asthma symptoms.
  • Understanding these cells could lead to new treatments for patients unresponsive to current therapies.
  • The research involved collaboration between multiple laboratories and is based on over a decade of research.
“When you can't breathe, nothing else matters.” - Roma Sehmi

The discovery of these immune cells reshapes our understanding of severe asthma, potentially paving the way for innovative treatment strategies.
newTitle: Chameleon-like Immune Cells May Worsen Asthma

title: Global Experts Propose Comprehensive Approach to Obesity Diagnosis Beyond BMI - Oneindia
summary:
Global Experts Propose Comprehensive Approach to Obesity Diagnosis Beyond BMI

Updated: Wednesday, January 15, 2025, 23:51 [IST] • Source: The Lancet Diabetes and Endocrinology

Experts worldwide are suggesting a fresh approach to defining and diagnosing obesity that reduces reliance on BMI and aims to better identify individuals needing treatment.

  • New recommendations propose combining BMI with waist circumference and other health problems.
  • Introduces new diagnostic categories: clinical obesity and pre-clinical obesity.
  • Approximately 20% of those previously classified as obese might no longer meet the new criteria.
  • Supported by over 75 medical organizations but faces challenges in adoption.
Dr. David Cummings: "The whole goal of this is to get a more precise definition so that we are targeting the people who actually need the help most."

Redefining obesity is a significant step, but practical challenges exist in measuring and training required for effective implementation.
newTitle: Global Experts Propose Comprehensive Approach to Obesity Diagnosis Beyond BMI

title: Different DNA Repair Mechanisms Drive Cancer Cell Death after Radiotherapy - Inside Precision Medicine
summary:
Different DNA Repair Mechanisms Drive Cancer Cell Death after Radiotherapy

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: Inside Precision Medicine

Scientists at the Children’s Medical Research Institute have uncovered how tumor cells die differently after radiotherapy, potentially paving the way for new cancer therapies.

  • DNA repair mechanisms determine the fate of cancer cells after radiation.
  • Some cells die quietly while others trigger an immune response.
  • Blocking DNA repair pathways may encourage immune response against cancer.
  • BRCA2 mutations affect cancer cell survival during treatment.
“The surprising result of our research is that DNA repair, which normally protects healthy cells, determines how cancer cells die following radiotherapy.” – Tony Cesare, PhD

This research could enhance radiation treatment efficacy and lead to more personalized cancer therapies by understanding tumor genetics and treatment responses.
newTitle: Different DNA Repair Mechanisms Drive Cancer Cell Death after Radiotherapy

title: Why monitoring outbreaks in animals key to track human cases of H5N1 - The Indian Express
summary:
Why monitoring outbreaks in animals key to track human cases of H5N1

Date: January 15, 2025 Source: Indian Express

Public health experts emphasize the necessity of monitoring and controlling poultry outbreaks of the AH5N1 virus, noting that while it does not spread between humans, vigilance is critical to prevent infections.

  • H5N1 poses a significant threat to poultry and can occasionally infect humans.
  • Recent cases in India involved bird flu in tigers and leopards, highlighting its potential spread in wildlife.
  • The CDC reported the first human death from H5N1 in the U.S., with global cases over 950.
  • Experts stress the importance of international cooperation and regular surveillance of outbreaks.
  • Human infections primarily result from handling infected birds without precautions.
“Importantly there is no person to person transmission and vigilance can help minimise the chance that the virus will make such adaptations.” – Dr Rajeev Jayadevan

In conclusion, monitoring outbreaks in animal populations is essential for public health, particularly to mitigate the risk of H5N1 virus transmission to humans.
newTitle: Importance of Monitoring Animal Outbreaks to Control H5N1 Human Cases

title: Does hand sanitizer kill norovirus? Here's what really works - The Times of India
summary:
Does Hand Sanitizer Kill Norovirus? Here's What Really Works

Publication Date: N/A Source: N/A

This article explores the effectiveness of hand sanitizer against norovirus, detailing what actually works for preventing the virus.

  • Hand sanitizers may not be effective against norovirus due to its resistance.
  • Washing hands with soap and water is recommended for greater effectiveness.
  • Norovirus is highly contagious and can survive on surfaces for extended periods.
“Alcohol-based hand sanitizers do not kill norovirus effectively.”

To effectively ward off norovirus, proper hand hygiene, especially hand washing with soap and water, is essential.
newTitle: Does Hand Sanitizer Kill Norovirus? Here's What Really Works

title: The link between obesity and cancer risk - Medical Xpress
summary:
Understanding the Link Between Obesity and Cancer Risk

Publication Date: January 15, 2025 | Source: Medical Xpress

Obesity is increasingly recognized as a health issue linked to several cancers. A new review in Frontiers of Medicine sheds light on the mechanisms and suggests clinical implications.

  • Key mechanisms of obesity influencing cancer include inflammation, hormonal imbalances, and gut microbiota dysregulation.
  • Chronic inflammation in adipose tissue is a significant factor in cancer development.
  • Hormonal changes, especially elevated estrogen levels, are relevant for cancer risks, particularly in postmenopausal women.
  • Dietary and lifestyle modifications, such as weight management and physical activity, can reduce cancer risks associated with obesity.
  • Bariatric surgery has demonstrated efficacy in decreasing cancer incidence.
“The review underscores the need for a deeper understanding of the mechanisms linking obesity and cancer to develop personalized prevention and treatment strategies.”

Further research is vital to unravel the complex interactions between obesity and cancer.
newTitle: Understanding the Link Between Obesity and Cancer Risk

title: Why a daily glass of milk really could reduce bowel cancer risk – an oncologist explains - The Indian Express
summary:
Daily Milk Consumption Could Lower Bowel Cancer Risk, Study Finds

Publication Date: October 2023 | Source: Indian Express

A new study from Oxford University and Cancer Research UK indicates that consuming an extra glass of milk daily may significantly reduce the risk of bowel cancer, with nearly 45,000 cases reported annually in the UK.

  • The research implies that just one additional glass daily could lower cancer risk.
  • A 17% reduced risk of bowel cancer was found for those consuming an extra 244g of milk daily.
  • Calcium in milk is suggested to play a protective role against cancer.
  • The study analyzed data from over 542,000 participants to determine the impacts of milk consumption.
  • Additional lifestyle changes like reducing alcohol and processed meat can also help lower cancer risk.
“Overall, this groundbreaking research provides compelling evidence for the potential role of milk consumption in reducing bowel cancer risk.”

This study highlights the potential of simple dietary changes in improving public health outcomes and encourages further research into diet's role in disease prevention.
newTitle: Daily Milk Consumption Could Lower Bowel Cancer Risk, Study Finds

title: Does obesity affect children’s likelihood of survival after being diagnosed with cancer? - WebWire
summary:
Does obesity affect children’s likelihood of survival after being diagnosed with cancer?

Date Published: Wednesday, January 15, 2025 | Source: WEBWIRE

A recent study reveals that obesity at diagnosis significantly decreases survival rates among children diagnosed with cancer, suggesting a need for strategies to mitigate these risks.

  • 10.5% of children with cancer were obese at the time of diagnosis.
  • Lower 5-year event-free survival rates were observed in obese children (77.5%) compared to non-obese children (79.6%).
  • Obesity was linked to a 16% increase in relapse risk and a 29% increase in risk of death.
  • The impact is particularly significant for those with acute lymphoblastic leukemia and brain tumors.
“Our study highlights the negative impact of obesity among all types of childhood cancers. It provides the rationale to evaluate different strategies to mitigate the adverse risk of obesity on cancer outcomes in future trials,” said co–senior author Thai Hoa Tran, MD.

This research underscores the urgent need to address childhood obesity due to its serious implications on health and survival outcomes in pediatric cancer patients.
newTitle: Obesity Linked to Lower Survival Rates in Children with Cancer

How to lower dementia risk factors: Why does a US study on Afro-Americans hold clues for Indians? - The Indian Express
summary:
How to lower dementia risk factors: Why does a US study on Afro-Americans hold clues for Indians?

Publication Date: January 15, 2025

Source: Indian Express

New findings reveal a potential increase in US dementia cases, especially among Afro-Americans, which carries critical implications for dementia management in India.

  • Projected growth in dementia cases in the US from 514,000 in 2020 to around 1 million by 2060.
  • Prevention could reduce 30% of dementia cases globally, focusing on lifestyle factors like diabetes control and social connections.
  • Indian population faces a high burden of dementia, primarily mixed and vascular conditions.
  • Increased risk factors include rising diabetes and hypertension rates among younger populations.
  • Policy changes and enhanced health literacy are crucial for dementia prevention in India.
“If you take preventive steps at the right time, 30% of the dementia cases could be reduced globally.” - Dr. M. V. Padma Srivastava

Strengthening preventive health measures and awareness is vital to mitigate the rising dementia trend and enhance overall public health.
newTitle: How to Lower Dementia Risk: Insights from a US Study on Afro-Americans for India

Pesticides to heavy metals: Know how environmental toxins can lead to blood cancer - Hindustan Times
summary:
Environmental Toxins and Their Link to Blood Cancer

Date: Jan 15, 2025 Source: Hindustan Times

This article explores how environmental toxins contribute to blood cancers such as Leukaemia, Lymphoma, and Myeloma, highlighting important insights from an oncologist.

  • Environmental toxins like benzene, pesticides, and heavy metals can lead to blood cancer.
  • Long-term exposure to benzene is linked to an increased risk of Acute Myeloid Leukaemia (AML).
  • Some pesticides are associated with a higher risk of Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma and other blood cancers.
  • Heavy metals such as arsenic and ionizing radiation contribute to the development of blood cancers.
  • Preventative measures include using protective gear in high-risk jobs and regular screenings for blood abnormalities.
“Environmental toxins are contributors to inciting mutations and disturbance in the hematopoietic system of the body.” - Dr. Shivali Ahlawat

This discussion underscores the importance of addressing environmental toxins as critical factors in blood cancer development and emphasizes the need for preventative strategies.
newTitle: Environmental Toxins and Their Link to Blood Cancer

Are your teeth misaligned? Ultra-processed foods are to blame - Firstpost
summary:
Are your teeth misaligned? Ultra-processed foods are to blame

Publication Date: [Publication Date Placeholder] Source: [Source Placeholder]

A recent study has highlighted the adverse effects of ultra-processed foods on children's jaw development, indicating a worrying trend in dental health.

  • Scientists have found that ultra-processed foods contribute to smaller jawbones in children.
  • These foods include soft drinks, ice cream, and breakfast cereals, which are often high in calories and sugars.
  • The diet is linked to issues like dental overcrowding, crooked teeth, and malocclusion.
“Chewing plays a crucial role in the proper development of the jaws as it stimulates bone growth, strengthens facial muscles, and promotes proper dental alignment.” - Laura Marques Martinez

This research underscores the importance of diet in dental health, prompting a reevaluation of food choices for children.
newTitle: Ultra-Processed Foods Linked to Dental Issues in Children

Gujarat: Four-year-old boy tests positive for HMPV; fifth case in Ahmedabad in 10 days - Deccan Herald
summary:
Four-Year-Old Boy Tests Positive for HMPV in Ahmedabad

Published: January 15, 2025, 14:06 IST

Ahmedabad has reported five cases of human metapneumovirus (HMPV) in just ten days, with a new case being a four-year-old boy.

  • A total of six HMPV cases have been reported in Gujarat so far.
  • The boy was admitted to Zydus Hospital with cough, cold, and fever on January 13.
  • Three of the cases are from Ahmedabad, with one each reported from Rajasthan and Kutch district.
  • The outbreak of HMPV gained attention following a recent outbreak in China.
  • HMPV is a viral pathogen that affects people of all ages, causing respiratory infections.
“Today, a four-year-old male child was detected with HMPV infection.” - Bhavin Solanki, Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation medical officer of health

This increase in HMPV cases raises concerns about respiratory health, particularly following its recent outbreak in other countries.
newTitle: Four-Year-Old Boy Tests Positive for HMPV in Ahmedabad

title: Smells Like Protein Spirit - Longreads
summary:
Smells Like Protein Spirit

Date: June 20, 2024 | Source: Taste

Protein has become a dominant force in the food industry, heavily promoted by influencers and integrated into an array of food products. This article examines the phenomenon known as the 'proteinization of food' and its growing prevalence in consumer culture.

This trend, which echoes and rhymes with various food and dietary fads over the last 25 years, is reaching something like an observable popular crescendo now, impacting our grocery shelves, our refrigerators, and our conception of the self as informed by the symbiotic relationship we’ve formed with our phones.

  • The trend of incorporating excessive amounts of protein into foods is affecting consumer behavior and product offerings in grocery stores.
  • Many products, including snacks and beverages, are now marketed with high protein content as a selling point.
  • Influencers and social media play a significant role in promoting protein consumption and the related lifestyle.

As this trend continues, the concept of food and dietary intake is shifting, reflecting a deeper interaction with the content consumers engage with online.
newTitle: The Proteinization of Food: A Trend on the Rise

title: Stress and sleepless nights are wreaking havoc on your digestion? Expert tips to get things moving again - Hindustan Times
Drink three cups of green tea every day to prevent the risk of these brain diseases: Study - Hindustan Times
summary:
Drink Three Cups of Green Tea Daily to Reduce Brain Disease Risk, Study Shows

Date: January 15, 2025 | Source: Hindustan Times

Recent research indicates that consuming green tea can significantly contribute to preserving brain health and mitigating the risk of neurodegenerative diseases such as Alzheimer’s.

  • Green tea contains antioxidants that are beneficial for brain health.
  • A study found that drinking 600 ml of green tea daily resulted in 3% less brain damage than consuming 200 ml or less.
  • Participants consuming green tea showed fewer cerebral white matter lesions, which are linked to cognitive decline.
  • The study highlights the unique benefits of green tea over coffee in terms of protecting brain health.
“The drinking of green tea may help reduce future vascular damage in the brain.”

This study underscores the importance of green tea as a simple dietary change that could have significant health benefits, especially in aging populations.
newTitle: Drink Three Cups of Green Tea Daily to Reduce Brain Disease Risk, Study Shows

title: Drinking over 1 alcoholic beverage a day sharply increases death risk - The Times of India
summary:
Drinking over 1 alcoholic beverage a day sharply increases death risk

Published on: Tuesday, Source: Department of Health and Human Services

A new federal review reveals that consuming more than one drink a day significantly raises the risk of premature death, prompting experts to consider stricter guidelines as the US updates dietary recommendations.

  • The risk of dying from alcohol use is 1 in 1000 for those consuming more than 7 drinks per week.
  • The risk increases to 1 in 100 for those consuming more than 9 drinks per week.
  • Current guidelines recommend men to limit intake to two drinks and women to one drink per day.
  • Excessive alcohol consumption is linked to liver, brain issues, addiction, and various cancers.
  • The true health risks of alcohol may be underestimated due to research limitations.
"Once you're over a drink a day, your risk of dying from alcohol is already above one percent." - Dr. Timothy Naimi

The review underlines the diverse health risks associated with alcohol consumption and emphasizes the need for updated dietary guidelines to mitigate these risks.
newTitle: Drinking over 1 alcoholic beverage a day sharply increases death risk

title: Drinking over 1 alcoholic beverage a day sharply increases death risk, federal review finds - The Times of India
summary:
Drinking over 1 alcoholic beverage a day sharply increases death risk, federal review finds

Date: October 2023 | Source: Health Wellness Journal

This article discusses a federal review that reveals the significant health risks associated with consuming more than one alcoholic beverage per day, indicating a sharp increase in the risk of death.

  • The review emphasizes the correlation between heavy alcohol consumption and increased mortality rates.
  • It suggests that even moderate drinking can have serious health implications.
  • Health experts urge individuals to reconsider their alcohol intake.
"Alcohol consumption is a significant risk factor for various health issues, including cancer and cardiovascular diseases."

This review highlights the urgent need for public health initiatives aimed at reducing alcohol consumption and raising awareness about its potential dangers.
newTitle: Drinking More Than 1 Alcoholic Beverage a Day Linked to Higher Death Risk

title: 4 signs of fatty liver visible on a person's body - The Times of India
summary:
4 Signs of Fatty Liver Visible on a Person's Body

Publication Date: Not specified, Source: Health Wellness Journal

This article discusses the physical signs that may indicate the presence of fatty liver disease, a condition that can lead to serious health complications.

  • Physical symptoms of fatty liver include weight gain and abdominal discomfort.
  • Yellowing of the skin or eyes (jaundice) may also be a sign of liver issues.
  • Fatigue and weakness are common complaints among those affected.
  • Some individuals may experience swelling in the abdomen or legs due to fluid retention.
“Fatty liver disease is often asymptomatic in its early stages, making it crucial to be aware of these signs.”

In conclusion, recognizing the physical signs of fatty liver disease is important for early diagnosis and treatment, potentially preventing more severe liver damage.
newTitle: 4 Signs of Fatty Liver Visible on a Person's Body

title: Scientists discover common virus could be causing Alzheimer's disease - India Today
summary:
Scientists discover common virus could be causing Alzheimer’s disease

Published On: Jan 15, 2025 | Source: India Today

Researchers have found a link between a common virus and Alzheimer's disease, which is the most common type of dementia affecting memory and behavior.

  • CMV, a type of herpesvirus, often infects individuals in childhood and remains dormant.
  • By age 80, around 90% of individuals have CMV antibodies.
  • The virus may exploit the vagus nerve pathway, potentially triggering immune reactions in the brain.
  • This virus-related Alzheimer's subtype may account for 25–45% of cases, showing unique biological profiles alongside classic signs.
  • CMV antibodies were found in tissues from donors with Alzheimer's, linking the virus to the disease.
  • Early detection of active CMV infections could lead to preventative antiviral treatments.
“This virus-related Alzheimer's subtype may account for 25–45% of cases.” - Dr. Ben Readhead

The discovery of a link between CMV and Alzheimer's could reshape approaches to prevention and treatment, emphasizing the need for early detection of infections.
newTitle: Scientists discover common virus could be causing Alzheimer’s disease
